Find all files with the given name in current + child directories:

find . -name 'some_file_name'

Find all files with the given name in current directory:

find . -maxdepth 1 -name 'some_file_name'

Find all files that donâ€™t match the given name:

find -not -name 'some_file_name'

Find all files that contain the given string:

find . -type f -exec grep -l 'some_string' {} +

Find all files with the given extension that contain the given string:

find . -type f -name "*.'some_extension'" -exec grep -l 'some_string' {} +

Find all files with the given extensions that contain the given string:

find . -type f -name \( -name "*.'some_extension'" -o -name "*.'some_extension'" \) -exec grep -l 'some_string' {} +

Find all files without the given extension that contain the given string:

find . -type f ! -name "*.'some_extension'" -exec grep -l "some_string' {} +

Find and replace string in all files in the current + child directories:

find . -type f -name -exec sed -i "s/'some_string_to_replace'/'some_string_to_replace_with'/g" *

Compressing directory/files:

tar -zcvf 'some_file_name.tar.gz' 'some_directory_name' 'some_file_name' 'some_file_name'
#z: compress using gzip
#c: create archive
#v: enable verbose mode
#f: archive file name

Split a string based on a delimiter and print it:

echo "*'some_delimeter'*" | awk -F "'some_delimeter'" "{print $1}"

Printing the first string in the second row:

echo "some_string" | awk "NR==2 {print $1}"
